name: Interlaken
fun_fact: Fun fact: The Jungfrau Railway, built between 1896-1912, took 16 years to construct as workers inched through solid rock to create Europe's highest railway station at 3,454m (11,332 ft). The original plan was to reach the Jungfrau summit itself with an elevator, but WWI halted the complete project. It's one of only four railways in the world using three-phase electric power.

hero_dishes.name: Cheese Fondue
hero_dishes.description: Melted cheese (traditionally GruyÃ¨re and Vacherin) served in a communal pot with bread cubes for dipping
hero_dishes.origin_story: The ultimate alpine bonding experience, traditionally enjoyed after a day of hiking or skiing. Local tradition says if you drop your bread in the cheese, you owe the next round of schnapps! The original recipe uses alcohol, though some restaurants offer apple juice versions.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Fondue Villa & Garden (offers classic Swiss, mushroom, tomato, and vegan almond fondues with stunning Alps views, plus cooking classes), Gasthof BÃ¤ren in Wilderswil (authentic in old chalet setting), Restaurant Stadthaus (historic setting)

hero_dishes.name: Raclette
hero_dishes.description: Half-wheel of raclette cheese melted by open fire and scraped onto potatoes, pickles, and cured meats
hero_dishes.origin_story: Less 'dip your bread' and more 'smother everything in cheese.' Traditionally, raclette originated in the canton of Valais where alpine herders would melt cheese by the fire. A unique experience is raclette at the St. Beatus caves or Stockhorn caves.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gasthof BÃ¤ren in Wilderswil, Taverne Interlaken, and cave experiences at St. Beatus or Stockhorn

hero_dishes.origin_story: Originally a farmer's breakfast in Bern, rÃ¶sti is now served throughout the country for lunch or dinner. Regional variations include the Bern version with cheese, onions, and bacon. Some creative chefs make versions with gorgonzola, pear, and onions.

hero_dishes.name: Ã„lplermagronen (Alpine Macaroni)
hero_dishes.description: Macaroni baked with potatoes, cream, onions, and cheese, topped with caramelized onions and served with applesauce
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented in the 1930s when Italian workers brought pasta to Switzerland. Alpine herdsmen quickly adopted it because all ingredients (pasta, cheese, cream, onions, potatoes) were readily available in the mountains. It's like American mac and cheese, but better.
